factsCard.description: Discover the remarkable features and achievements of the United States of America. The USA boasts incredible geographic, economic, cultural, and innovative significance on the world stage.

facts.title: Third Largest Country
facts.description: The USA is the third largest country in both land area and population, after Russia/Canada (area) and China/India (population).

facts.title: 50 States & 1 Federal District
facts.description: It's made up of 50 states and Washington, D.C., which is the capital but not a state.

facts.title: World's Largest Economy
facts.description: As of now, the United States has the largest economy in the world, driven by technology, finance, healthcare, and entertainment.

facts.title: Cultural Diversity
facts.description: It's one of the most culturally diverse countries, with over 350 languages spoken and communities from almost every country on Earth.

facts.title: Innovations Originated Here
facts.description: The USA is home to many inventions ‚Äî including the internet, airplane, lightbulb, and iPhone.

movingCostsGuide.title: How Much Does It Cost to Move to the USA?
movingCostsGuide.description: Moving to the United States can be exciting, but it comes with several costs you should plan for. Here's a detailed breakdown of the expenses you can expect when relocating to the USA.

costSections.title: Visa & Immigration Fees
costSections.details: Visa applications, green card, optional attorney fees

costSections.title: Flight Tickets
costSections.details: One-way flight depending on location and booking time

costSections.title: Shipping Belongings
costSections.details: Depends on volume and shipping method

costSections.title: Initial Accommodation
costSections.details: First month's rent + deposit (varies by city)

categories.title: Single Person
categories.description: Includes visa fees, initial housing, transportation and basic setup costs

categories.title: Family of Four
categories.description: Includes all costs for the entire family including visas, shipping, and accommodation

tips.title: Consider Location Carefully
tips.description: Housing costs vary dramatically between cities. Consider smaller cities or suburbs.

tips.title: Book Flights Early
tips.description: Booking flights 2-3 months in advance can save hundreds of dollars.

tips.title: Ship Selectively
tips.description: Consider what's worth shipping vs. buying new in the USA.

tips.title: Compare Insurance Plans
tips.description: Health insurance costs can vary widely; invest time in finding the right plan.

movingCostsGuide.conclusion: Your final cost depends heavily on your visa type, where you're moving from, and your destination in the U.S. With proper planning and budgeting, you can make your move to the United States both smooth and economical.

requirements.title: Obtain the Right Visa or Green Card
requirements.description: You must have an approved visa or a Green Card (permanent resident status) to live in the U.S.
details: Family-based immigrant visa
Employment-based visa (H-1B, L-1, etc.)
Student visa (F-1)
Green Card Lottery (Diversity Visa Program)
requirements.tip: Start your visa application at the U.S. embassy or consulate in your country. Processing times vary from weeks to months.

requirements.title: Valid Passport
requirements.description: Your passport must be valid for at least 6 months beyond your intended date of entry.
details: Renew it before applying for the visa if it's about to expire.

requirements.title: Approved Medical Examination
requirements.description: A mandatory medical exam is required for immigrant visas.
details: This must be done by a U.S. embassy-approved physician.
You'll be screened for diseases like tuberculosis and required to show proof of key vaccinations.
requirements.tip: Cost: Around $200‚Äì$400 depending on the country.

requirements.title: Vaccination & Health Records
requirements.description: Bring a complete record of vaccinations.
details: Measles, Mumps, Rubella (MMR)
Polio
Tetanus
Influenza (during flu season)
COVID-19 (as of the latest USCIS guidance)

requirements.title: Financial Proof or Sponsorship
requirements.description: You need to prove you won't become financially dependent on the U.S. government:
details: Employment visa: Job offer letter and salary details.
Family visa: Sponsor must file Form I-864 (Affidavit of Support) and show income above a set level.
Student visa: Proof of tuition payment and living expenses for at least one academic year.

requirements.title: Clean Criminal Record
requirements.description: Minor infractions usually don't disqualify you, but serious criminal records may result in visa denial.
details: Background checks are part of the process.

requirements.title: English Language Skills (Practical)
requirements.description: Not always required, but strongly recommended for work and daily life.
details: Some visas (like H-1B) expect proficiency.
If applying for citizenship later, English and civics knowledge are required.

requirements.title: Other Practical Requirements After Arrival
requirements.description: Once in the U.S., you'll need to:
details: Apply for a Social Security Number (SSN)
Open a U.S. bank account
Get a driver's license or ID
Find housing (rent or buy)
Buy health insurance (U.S. healthcare is private and expensive)

importantReminder.title: Important Reminder
importantReminder.description: Immigration requirements can change over time. This guide is based on current information, but always verify the most recent requirements with the U.S. Department of State or U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) before proceeding with your move.

header.title: Moving to the US from Turkey
header.description: Moving from Turkey to the United States can be a life-changing opportunity, but it requires proper planning and legal procedures. Here's what you need to know:

sections.title: Choose the Right Visa Type
sections.description: Your first step is securing the correct U.S. visa based on your reason for moving:

items.title: Family-Based Visa
items.description: If you have close family members who are U.S. citizens or permanent residents.

items.title: Employment Visa (H-1B, L-1, O-1)
items.description: If you're offered a job in the U.S.

items.title: Student Visa (F-1)
items.description: If you plan to study at a U.S. college or university.

items.title: Diversity Visa (Green Card Lottery)
items.description: Turkey is eligible ‚Äî you can apply during the annual lottery window.

items.title: Investor Visa (E-2)
items.description: For Turkish nationals who invest a substantial amount in a U.S. business.

sections.title: Prepare for the Visa Interview
sections.description: Apply at the U.S. Embassy in Ankara or Consulate in Istanbul, depending on your region. You'll need:

items.title: Valid passport
items.description: Ensure your passport is valid for at least 6 months beyond your planned stay.

items.title: Visa application
items.description: Form DS-160 or appropriate immigrant form.

items.title: Medical exam and vaccination records
items.description: Complete medical examination with an approved physician.

items.title: Private health insurance
items.description: The U.S. doesn't offer free healthcare ‚Äî you'll need to purchase private health insurance.

items.title: Higher cost of living
items.description: Cost of living is higher than Turkey. Rent, healthcare, and transportation are more expensive, especially in cities like New York, LA, or San Francisco.

items.title: Turkish communities
items.description: The U.S. is diverse, with many Turkish communities, especially in cities like New York, Chicago, and Los Angeles.

items.title: Different lifestyle
items.description: Daily life may be more individualistic and fast-paced compared to Turkey.

sections.title: After Arrival in the U.S.
sections.description: Once you arrive, make sure to:

items.title: Apply for a Social Security Number (SSN)
items.description: This is essential for working and filing taxes in the U.S.

items.title: Open a bank account
items.description: You'll need this for daily financial transactions.

items.title: Get a driver's license
items.description: Public transportation is limited in many areas of the U.S.

items.title: Find accommodation
items.description: And adjust to U.S. systems (education, work, transport).

footer.disclaimer: Remember that immigration requirements can change. Always check with the U.S. Embassy in Turkey or USCIS for the most current information.

header.title: Moving With Pets to the USA
header.description: Bringing your pet to the U.S. is possible, but you'll need to follow specific rules:

requirements.title: Rabies Vaccination
requirements.description: Mandatory for dogs; highly recommended for cats

requirements.title: Health Certificate
requirements.description: Issued by a licensed vet (usually within 10 days of travel)

requirements.title: Microchip
requirements.description: Not required by law, but highly recommended

requirements.title: Pet-friendly Airline Booking
requirements.description: Follow carrier rules for crate size, documents, and fees

arrivalInfo.title: Inspection
arrivalInfo.description: Pets may be inspected at the port of entry

arrivalInfo.title: No Quarantine
arrivalInfo.description: For pets from most countries (including the UK and Turkey), if paperwork is complete

tips: Start the process at least 4-6 weeks before your move
Check if your destination state has additional entry requirements
Bring enough of your pet's medication for the first few months
Consider pet transport services if traveling with multiple animals

footer.disclaimer: Always check with the USDA APHIS and your destination state's veterinary office for the most up-to-date requirements before traveling.

requirements.title: Valid Visa or Green Card
requirements.description: You must obtain the correct visa type based on your purpose (e.g., work, family, study).
requirements.note: Immigrant visas are required for permanent relocation.

requirements.title: Valid Passport
requirements.description: Your passport must be valid for at least 6 months beyond your intended stay.

requirements.title: Medical Examination
requirements.note: Must be done by an approved physician.

requirements.title: Vaccination Records
requirements.description: Proof of vaccinations (e.g., MMR, COVID-19, hepatitis) is needed for immigration.

requirements.title: Proof of Financial Support
requirements.description: You may need to show bank statements, job offers, or a sponsor to prove you won't become a public charge.

requirements.title: Clean Criminal Record
requirements.description: Background checks are part of the immigration process.
requirements.note: Serious offenses may lead to visa denial.

requirements.title: English Skills (Recommended)
requirements.description: Not mandatory for all visa types, but knowing English helps greatly in daily life, jobs, and education.

importantNote.title: Important Note
importantNote.description: Immigration requirements can change. Always verify the latest information from the U.S. Department of State or U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) before proceeding with your move.

header.title: Moving to the US from the UK
header.subtitle: What You Need to Know
header.description: Relocating from the UK to the United States is a major step that requires planning, legal documentation, and an understanding of how life differs across the Atlantic. Whether you're moving for work opportunities, to be with family, or for a new adventure, this guide covers the essential aspects of your transatlantic relocation.

sections.title: Visa Requirements
sections.content:
As a UK citizen, you'll need a visa to move to the U.S. long-term. Common options include:

  • ‚Ä¢Employment Visas (H-1B, L-1, O-1) ‚Äì For skilled professionals, transfers, or extraordinary abilities
  • ‚Ä¢Family-Based Green Card ‚Äì If you have immediate relatives who are U.S. citizens
  • ‚Ä¢Student Visa (F-1) ‚Äì If you're studying in the U.S.
  • ‚Ä¢Investor Visa (E-2) ‚Äì For UK citizens investing in a U.S. business

The visa application process requires careful planning, as rejection rates can be high for certain visa types.

sections.title: Visa Application Process
sections.content:
The visa application process involves several steps:

  • ‚Ä¢ Apply online via the U.S. Department of State
  • ‚Ä¢ Schedule an interview at the U.S. Embassy in London or Consulate in Belfast
  • ‚Ä¢ Prepare required documents:

Required Documents:

  • ‚Ä¢ Valid passport
  • ‚Ä¢ Visa application form
  • ‚Ä¢ Medical examination results
  • ‚Ä¢ Proof of finances
  • ‚Ä¢ Sponsor/job offer documentation if required
  • ‚Ä¢ Educational certificates (for certain visas)

sections.title: Healthcare & Insurance
sections.content:
Unlike the UK's NHS, U.S. healthcare is primarily private and can be expensive

You'll need to buy private health insurance ‚Äî monthly costs can range from $300‚Äì$700+ per person

Many employers offer health insurance as part of benefits packages

Consider insurance that covers emergency repatriation in the first year

üí°Tip: Start researching health insurance options before you arrive, and ensure you have coverage from day one in the U.S.

sections.title: Cost of Living Comparison
sections.content:
ExpenseUnited States (avg.)UK (avg.)
Rent (1-bed apartment)$1,200‚Äì$3,000¬£800‚Äì¬£1,200
Healthcare$300‚Äì$700/monthNHS (tax-funded)
Meal at restaurant$15‚Äì$30¬£10‚Äì¬£25
Transportation$70‚Äì$100/month (varies)¬£60‚Äì¬£120/month

Cost of living varies significantly by location. Major cities like New York, San Francisco, and Los Angeles are significantly more expensive than most UK cities including London.

sections.title: Finding Housing
sections.content:
The U.S. rental market moves quickly, especially in competitive cities

Most landlords require a credit check, which can be challenging for new arrivals

Consider short-term rentals when you first arrive until you're settled

Popular rental search websites: Zillow, Apartments.com, Trulia, Realtor.com

üí°Tip: Bring reference letters from UK landlords and proof of income to help overcome the lack of U.S. credit history.

sections.title: Banking & Finance
sections.content:
Opening a bank account

You'll need your passport, visa, proof of address, and potentially your Social Security Number (SSN).

Credit history

Your UK credit history doesn't transfer to the U.S. You'll need to build credit from scratch.

Tax considerations

As a UK expat, you'll need to file tax returns in both countries, though tax treaties help prevent double taxation.

Money transfers

Consider specialized forex services rather than banks for better exchange rates when moving money between the UK and US.

sections.title: Daily Life Adjustments
sections.content:
Driving

You'll drive on the right-hand side. Most states allow you to drive on your UK license for up to 3 months, after which you'll need a state license.

Tipping culture

Tipping is expected (15-20%) at restaurants, for taxis, and various services. Service staff rely on tips as part of their income.

Measurement system

The U.S. uses imperial measurements for most things (miles, pounds, Fahrenheit), which may require adjustment.

Mobile phones

Major carriers include AT&T, Verizon, and T-Mobile. Consider getting a local SIM card or plan upon arrival.

sections.title: Work Culture Differences
sections.content:
U.S. work culture often includes:

  • ‚Ä¢Fewer vacation days (typically 10-15 days vs. UK's 20-25)
  • ‚Ä¢More direct communication styles
  • ‚Ä¢Networking is highly valued and often expected
  • ‚Ä¢Work-life balance varies significantly by company

sections.title: Moving Logistics
sections.content:
International moving costs to the U.S. range from ¬£2,000-¬£10,000 depending on volume

Consider whether to ship or sell larger furniture items (U.S. homes often have different dimensions)

Customs clearance requires a detailed inventory of shipped items

Pets can enter the U.S. but must meet health and vaccination requirements

üí°Tip: For electronics, check voltage compatibility as the U.S. uses 110-120V (vs. UK's 230-240V).

sections.title: Settling In After Arrival
sections.content:
1. Get a Social Security Number (SSN)

Required for employment and many services
Visit your local Social Security Administration office with your passport and visa

2. Obtain a State ID or Driver's License

Visit your state's Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) or equivalent agency

3. Set up Utilities

Arrange electricity, water, gas, internet, and waste collection services

4. Register with the UK Consulate

Optional but recommended for emergency notifications

sections.title: British Expat Communities
sections.content:
The U.S. has large British expatriate communities in many cities, particularly:

New York
Los Angeles
Chicago
Boston
San Francisco

You'll find British pubs, social clubs, and Facebook groups that can be invaluable for networking and getting local advice from others who've made the same move.

finalChecklist.title: Final Checklist Before Moving to the US

items.text: Secure your visa or green card
Research housing in your destination city
Notify HMRC and other UK authorities
Plan for currency exchange and transfers
Research tax obligations in both countries

conclusion.title: Conclusion: Is Moving to the US Right for You?
conclusion.description: Moving to the United States offers tremendous opportunities but comes with significant challenges. The visa process can be lengthy, healthcare costs are high, and adjusting to American culture takes time. However, many British expatriates find the career opportunities, diverse landscapes, and lifestyle well worth the transition.
